Got this idea from some dude on Instagram

Used PETG for most of the build, very similar to the Concert LED Glow Stick in terms of circuitry but reliant on USB for power instead of battery

Still using the ESP32C3 SuperMini

Try 1: Ribbed design

Pretty complicated design (overengineered it a bit)

Â 

There's these 4 rib supports that is vertical

In the pic above is the ribs attached to the rib supports, might need some hot glue gun as the peg turns out to be quite short and the rib might pop upwards with little force

Above shows the light cover that will encircle the LED base. Honestly, I done goofed a bit during the build cuz I'm overly excited, but the procedure should be:

    1. Light Cover + rib supports

    1. 19cm ribs

    1. 17cm ribs

    1. 15cm ribs

    1. 13cm ribs

    1. 11cm ribs

    1. Lastly, then we add the LED base

Total items:

    • 3x 19cm diameter rib

    • 2x 17cm diameter rib

    • 2x 15cm diameter rib

    • 2x 13cm diameter rib

    • 2x 11cm diameter rib

    • 4x vertical rib supports

    • 1x light cover

    • 1x LED base

Try 2: Simplified Curving Cuboid Light Cover + LED Base

Here is the 1st alternative light cover, turns out it's a good idea to make the LED core/base to be modular.

In this case, I basically recycled the LED base, but simplified the overall design, no more ribs, just reuse the Light Cover from Try 1 and make it curve in Blender.

It looks way nicer than initially expected, looks pretty "artsy" if I may say so myself

Try 3: Hexagon Lattice Cylindrical Light Cover + LED Base

This the 3rd and last one I made for now, with fancy hexagon lattice pattern on cylinder.

items.content_html:
I forgot where I misplaced my old glow stick so I thought: Eh why not let's try to make one

Pic above is all the printed parts, I managed to get my hands on this extra dense (144 LEDs per meter) LED cable strip that already have silicone (I think it's silicone?)

First need to connect the LED stick into the center core

It felt a bit wobbly to me so I hotglue'd the stick to the center core

The Handle here have a hole that fits exactly the same place so that the wire from LED strip can go through. For now, it's not screwed in yet

Connect the ESP32 Supermini to the LED wires, had to bend the header pins cuz I underestimated how long it is and this hurts me in my soul LOL

Use the battery pack to cover the ESP32 on the base handle, then screw in 2 screws onto the base handle (out of 4 screw holes, 2 works well for me)

Also, while I know I made it for 4x AAA but I end up actually just using 3, total of 4.5V should be OK for the LED strip and the regulator on ESP32 supermini but 6V might be risky

ME6211 (regulator on board the typical ESP32 supermini) should be able to work up to 6V but really can't guarantee it cuz this one is generic module off Aliexpress and the WS2812 too only said DC5V, so I ended up just playing it safe for now

Screwed the center core to the light cover and the handle

Picked up a new trick recently to just make a flat rectangular peg like this, slot in the battery cover and just screw the other end.

It works!

I should remove the red LED that comes by default with ESP32s, I think it drains the battery more than the ESP32 when it's in deep sleep mode. Also the reason why it defaults to red after the brightness goes to 0 is cuz it's in sleep mode, and pressing the button again wakes it up and it have to start from the 1st color, which is red.

It looks like one of those Jedi Light daggers LOL and the white looks so good.

Link to the 3D part models are here below, you can try making one yourself if you're interested, also can view the 3D model directly on the Thingiverse website

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7132640

Code here, just use Arduino IDE and select ESP32C3

items.summary: First time trying out 3D printing some gear mechanism then actuating it with servo. Janky as all hell but it worked out kind of. Other than the gear part, everything else is pretty straight forward, ESP32 + SG90 Servo + WS2812 LED strips, Wi-Fi to…
items.content_html:
First time trying out 3D printing some gear mechanism then actuating it with servo. Janky as all hell but it worked out kind of. Other than the gear part, everything else is pretty straight forward, ESP32 + SG90 Servo + WS2812 LED strips, Wi-Fi to read NTP time, no comms or anything complicated.

The idea is to have something that can change the sign that a shop is closed, open or opening soon, then changes color according to which sign is being displayed.

"Wooden Gear Mechanism Convertible Open Closed Signs for Business" is the name for this item. Basically the same idea but I thought why not use servo? Then add a 3rd state called "opening soon"

Â 

Above is how it internally looks without the 3D plate, basically a central pillar for WS2812 LED strips to stick to, also triangular prism and I split it such that I am able to take out the central part without needing to disassemble the outer shell too

I swear it looks waaaayyyyy better IRL. This is the Open state, the plate is saying "OPEN è¥ä¸ä¸­". Maybe I should put a diffuser sheet behind the 3D-printed plate

This one looks clearer on camera maybe cuz I printed it first at a higher infill of 60% IIRC. The plate is saying "OPENING SOON å³å°è¥ä¸".

Man, this one looks the worst on camera even though it ain't that bad IRL. Supposed to say "CLOSED å·²æçâ. Although I know prior to this that "closed" is something like "da yang" colloquially but this is the first time I see it in writing which is pretty neat. I got these labelling suggestions off of ChatGPT too haha, I chose the more casual/less formal ones.

Encountered so much trouble with the gearing mechanisms, I put the usual 0.3mm tolerance but end up not that good (Possible too my 3D printer having some issues with the X-Y axis, the tolerances are all out of whack). The 0.5cm pegs on the rotating prism went into the bearing on each end is also really weak even at 90% infill, I end up using soldering tip at 250C to melt the peg's layers together, then reinforcing some more with a small piece of filament.

I think I printed 3-4 times for the gears to trial and error which one works the best. If you are wondering why I went out of my way to use gears: The servo itself can only rotate from 0 to 180 deg, the prism in this case is 360/3 = 120 deg from one side to the next. Thus, at least i need to have something that can rotate from 0 to 240 deg cuz the prism need to be able to rotate through 3 states. I just used 2 to 1 gear ratio to expand the total rotation from 180 to 360.

YT vid above is the signage rotation test (i.e. literally just change between states). There's also a custom function to gradually change the servo angle, the original one is way too fast (basically just servo.write(targetAngle) with no intermediate angles) and it always end up oscillating at the correct position. You can notice too that the servo motion is smoother when I apply a bit of friction using my finger.

Either way I think I should just get a better servo haha, this SG90 is cheap AND old (2-3 years at least).

Currently the configuration array is something like this (I spent quite a bit of time trying to figure out the best angle for each state and even now Closed state still have a slightly awkward angle, it's worse at first cuz the best angle is smack dab right in the dead zone between 0 and 180, around 182 or -2(actually invalid inputs))

items.title: Massive 3D-Printed 7-Segment LED Clock
items.summary: Pretty ancient build. Built this like back in 2023, 1st unit is still in SG right now as of 2025, 2nd unit is in Indonesia at my dad's business (LOL apparently the damn thing is so bright it can been seen across the street from…
items.content_html:
Pretty ancient build. Built this like back in 2023, 1st unit is still in SG right now as of 2025, 2nd unit is in Indonesia at my dad's business (LOL apparently the damn thing is so bright it can been seen across the street from the shophouse at night)

1st unit is truly a trial run of an idea, only show hours and minutes while 2nd unit has seconds also.

Pic above is unit 1 that's in SG, you can see the trapezoidal connection points to the right and left of each digit

Pic above is the back view, basically just 3 wires coming out of the each digit and connecting to the next one. Look at the rectangle patches inside the build, those are LED strips that I cut and then manually connected with solder.

Unit 2 at my dad's shop back home ("depot air minum" (water filtration shop) in Indonesian, might be a really strange concept for S'poreans), look at the seconds, 2 more digits compared to unit 1. Also I have a criminal lack of photos of this unit, I had to dig through my chatlogs to find this photo. Good thing I made this thing modular to begin with, quite easy to stuff the modules into my dad's baggage and just haul it back home and then reassembling by himself.

The 3D printing is the least of my problem, the soldering afterwards is VERY time consuming if I don't plan ahead. I made them digit by digit and then just connect the wires together, i.e. the 1st hour digit goes to the left of 2nd hour digit and so on and so forth. This is possible cuz I used the WS2812B LED strip with their own individually programmable LEDs and if you have used them before, you will also know this LED have input and output + VCC and GND. The idea is to chain these RGB LEDs together and you can address them one by one in a line.

Here's a sample of WS2812 LED strip, you can see the DO and DI

Used light diffuser plates on each segment of the digits for the first time ever and it's a very interesting material. Only problem is the gluing onto the print, I used hot glue and it might fall off after some time, but this one holds up 2 years later so I guess it is better than originally expected.

Difference in code

Unit 2 is an improvement on unit 1. Unit 1 connects to Wi-Fi to get the local time, then update accordingly. It will do a check every hour to verify that it's still the correct time.

Unit 2 has seconds and I added an offline version (well, I call it offline cuz the original requires Wi-Fi, thus that one is online). More complicated cuz I had to simulate an actual clock + occasional check if it can connect to the designated Wi-Fi SSID.

IIRC I even added buttons and switches to do the whole offline value up-down thing (like an actual clock with the dial) while displaying the numbers and everything. All around troublesome and hilariously, in the end, my dad ended up using the original Wi-Fi mode anyway cuz that one sets up everything automatically. Oh well, good practice.

Conclusion

Overall, I think it's a promising product to sell but the time it takes to just make 1 is like 1 week minimum and there's lots of soldering to do. The fastest way is to perhaps make PCBs for each segment and then using just headers or something to connect the different PCBs together.

Oh wait hang on jumper wires might just work, easy solution, no crimping no soldering, just make sure it sticks around with hot glue and the size of the build will definitely be able to accommodate jumper wires.

items.title: IoT Dust Sensor Revisited: SAMD21, SERCOM &amp; PCB
items.summary: This is an old project, basically a private continuation of a project at a research engineer stint. ( SIT, back in 2021 I think? ) The original project wants a sensor that can dual use 4G and Wi-Fi to publish data onto Thingspeak. Honestly, 4G…
items.content_html:
Background on the original unit

This is an old project, basically a private continuation of a project at a research engineer stint. ( SIT, back in 2021 I think? )

The original project wants a sensor that can dual use 4G and Wi-Fi to publish data onto Thingspeak. Honestly, 4G is a hassle to use cuz the module itself is huge and a 4G SIM card is an all around pain to acquire. First time I tried using Arduino Nano 33 IOT, quite a neat project to use, especially with OTA Arduino. Although I would have to say the module is more limited than ESP32 if we have lots of peripherals.

It uses this "SERCOM" thing (SAMD21, the microcontroller on the Arduino Nano 33 can reconfigure itself to use different modes of the same pins) for communication protocols, there's like 6 of them, 1 is connected by default to Wi-Fi, so 5 left, 1 for SD card, 1 for BME280, 1 for 4G module, 2 Dust Sensors.

Honestly, the lack of software serial support ala older Arduinos and ESP32 is baffling, for dust sensors, we don't even need high speed serial, just 9600 baud is enough but it's not doable here and we need to do backflips to reconfigure the SERCOM.

Above is the PCB used in the research stint. Much credit to Prof. Kiew who gave me pointers on how to use copper area and also via signal grounding. I used to treat PCB as "thinner breadboards that can do SMD components" prior to this.

Also taught me the "place 2 squares on PCB right next to each other, then just solder for selection" trick. Pretty neat

Also got a pretty good lesson at making sure I give a value at the "spoke width" setting on the Copper Area in EasyEDA. No spoke width means the GND is completely fused to the Copper Area and makes it harder to solder cuz the heat get spread around very quickly.

Hilariously enough, this one is actually the 'V3' back then, V2 is developed by a student and I actually managed to find where he got the idea for the components from (he chose Teensy 3.2 (I can't figure out where to buy those even back in 2021), I personally prefer ESP32 (cheap and easy to get), Prof prefers Arduino ( more expensive but very standardized and high quality), that's an awfully specific choice). Looks like he followed a dust sensor tutorial online, but at least he got it working before I joined, so I didnât have to spend too many braincells reverse-engineering it.

Quick spin-off PCB for student

I think this one above is a "spin-off variant" for one of Prof. Kiew's student's FYP. I vaguely remember the double microcontroller set up. I think he uses the design for the next spin-off project within SIT.

The very first design before this didn't really work out, can't really help it though, I think its her first time designing a PCB and is confused with how it works. I ended up remaking it anyway after she submitted it and graduated, oh well. Hopefully it was still a good learning experience for her, first boards are almost always scuffed, no shame in that

The private build I made (Ver. Me V1)

This is sensor that I dug out from my stash, the components are all the same except the lack of 4G module. Changed the BME280 to BME680 (forgot why, maybe more features?). I also remembered changing one of the dust sensor too, SEN54 is a more advanced dust sensor compared to the one used in the SIT V3.

Schematic here, used my favorite ESP32 instead of the original Arduino Nano 33 IoT, everything else is pretty straight forward. Power is mostly USB, I make a socket for USB cable in the casing to power the ESP32, the rest just take power from either the 5V USB or 3.3V ESP32 regulator.

This is the V1 PCB, I tried to cram everything as much as possible, there's also an RGB LED to do a greater variety of indicator lighting.

Maybe I should add a screen and battery to a V2. Or maybe I can also make a central IOT hub that can connect to multiple sensors and visualize the data streams in multiple locations, that would be interesting. Probably gonna move on from ThingSpeak used in the SIT V3, 20s update (free account) is way too laggy and the transmission can be quite hit or miss.

items.content_html:
Introduction

Me love tank treads, tank treads are love, tank treads are life.

Jokes aside, tank treads are a huge pain in the ass to make, 3D printing is one thing, making them (i.e. joining them all together into a tread) is another.

Do note that this project is old, I think at least 2 years old from the day this post is written. I wouldn't be the least bit surprised if the PLA has started to crumble.

IIRC back then, I used this "gardening steel wire" that I got from a hardware store across the street. It got the job done but my hand is aching by the time I'm done.

I circled the gardening wires I used between the treads, basically ram em in, bend to 90 degrees, then use a really huge plier to cut them, hoping the bent wire will keep itself there naturally

it's a pretty hacky job but works decently enough

Wah I forgot where's the Arduino Nano for this. This is when you know the project is ancient, I'm still using Arduino Nano + NRF24L01. These days I just use ESP32 and wing the controls with Wi-Fi. I don't remember where I misplaced the NRF24 controller too, dang it all past me, why would you do this?

Some upgrades I am planning (will add later on when I am more available):

  1. Longer Tank treads, maybe 1.5 times longer, last time I thought this thing looks too cute and stubby for my liking

  2. Double Tensioning wheels at the top instead of 1

  3. Double wheels at the bottom of the treads so that it has an easier time rolling

  4. ESP32, keep NRF24L01 design, add 1 switch to select between Wi-Fi mode and NRF24 mode.

  5. More Power? Currently, we are using 3S LiPo battery, which might not be too good at this. Dang it tho, also possible the geared motor is not as fast to begin with cuz it has gearbox, it prioritizes strength and size, not speed. Maybe need to bite the bullet and get 2 of those mini4WD motors that can run at mach jesus RPM, but this one is way easier to couple to the 3D prints tho :'^(

  6. BONUS: Android App that can simulate a RC controller, perhaps use it to send control signals, though I am doubtful this is going to be viable any time soon. Now that I put in more than 2 minutes of thought into this, perhaps it will work best with BLE. Phone connects thru BLE, app send BLE signals, ESP32 interpret BLE signals

Remaking the tank treads but now in PETG instead of PLA

PETG should last longer than PLA, surprisingly OK material. Higher temperature needed at 240/80C. Bought them cuz ChatGPT suggested it might be better for 3D printing custom guitar necks (really long story)

Some images of the tank treads how I connected them with one another before I embark on this maddening journey of wire bending. If you're wondering, I used steel wire as "connector" instead of 3D printing it is cuz 3D printed pegs sucks, especially at that size (2-3mm max is weak af, especially if it need to withstand vibration and movements)

Steps are like:

  1. Clean the print up, slice out the supports (kinda regretted using the brim one, forgot to change it prior to print)

  2. Eyeball how much garden steel wire you need (Got the 0.9mm one from Daiso, works pretty well, I think the previous one uses 1.2mm cuz I remembered needing to use a vice drill to enlarge the hole a bit

  3. Cut out a bunch of small ~1.5cm wire pieces, bend one end to around 90 degrees (just roughly is fine)

  4. Insert the straight end to the max, use plier to bend the other end in the same direction as where you bent in step 3 (VERY IMPORTANT)

  5. Rotate the wire so that its perpendicular to the tank tread (Can be pokey and sharp cuz steel wire)

  6. Use plier to squeeze the 2 bent sides against the print (Don't need too hard, just enough to make it hold nicely)

  7. Repeat until you get 2 tank treads. (For me, each side has 30 pieces, 30x2 = 60 pieces in total. 120 wires in total needed :'^| )

Honestly, hard to convey how to do it, but as long as you get the rough idea and what each step is trying to do is fine, adapt it to the tools you have at hand.

New PETG tank treads completed, now at 30 treads each side, the old one is at 27 treads each side

[BONUS] New Android based BLE Remote Controller

UPDATE: TADA!!! Hauled ass a bit to make a quick Android app, used ChatGPT (i.e. vibe coded) and it's a bit confusing cuz I'm really new to Kotlin and Android app development. I'm half considering maybe I should make like 4 seekbars instead of 2 but that's not the priority for now. Now I have a quick way to test movements in addition to ESP32 Access Points and NRF24L01.

Done a quick test using the Modular Line following robot kit I was developing last month. Can't use the tank treaded one yet cuz I'm still soldering the new PCB to accommodate ESP32

On normal phone (Pls don't mind the shitty looking phone case, the TPU print is falling apart, I want to make a new one but I haven't got time to think of what new features to add and if you are wondering what's so special with this one, it's got external heatsinks on the backside)

On Android tablet

Sacrificed range and speed compared to NRF24L01, comparing the 3 methods and why I bothered to make something like this: (Different for ESP32-S3 and newer ones probably, I'm talking about the cheapest & classic WROOM)

Also depends on level of difficulty in making the UI / controller, NRF24L01 need physical remote controller and another Arduino to make it work, Wi-Fi AP is troublesome cuz I am not a JS wizard and I can only use limited functions like buttons and text inputs, BLE need to use Android phones (at least for this one), and Android is somewhat simpler to implement custom features like joysticks etc (This one uses just seekbars lmao)

TBH, I also know ESP-NOW and MQTT are viable options for this usage, but eh, I'm way too used to NRF24L01 compared to ESP-NOW, and MQTT need to use other people's MQTT server, which is troublesome in its own way.

This YT vid here is the "dual mode", 1st mode is tank controls (left side - right side controls) and 2nd mode is conventional RC controls (left is forward / backward, right is left / right)

[BONUS 2] Old Arduino Mega Based NRF24L01 Remote Controller

This is the front view of the NRF24L01 Controller that I refurbished a couple of months back, Arduino Mega is big chungus holy moly. The PCB can accommodate 2 mini OLEDs (I2C type), 6 buttons, 6 trimmers and 4 joystick modules.

Why so many? Just for fun haha, also I compressed the overall range of the joystick (resolution 1024 for Arduinos, 4096 for ESP32) into 1 byte (256).

Why compression? I realized halfway thru typing out "100" occupies 3 whole bytes already, and the transmission sometimes gets garbled, so better to compress if you don't need the resolution.

In addition, I think even 4 bits is enough cuz these joysticks are really not that precise and you end up maxxing it right away.

This is the back view of the same NRF24L01 Controller. The casing is new and I crammed as many batteries as I can, I think Arduino's regulator can withstand above 12V? This one is 8*1.5V, just nice 12V too.

The wiring is a bit messy and is also cuz this is not "casing" in the strictest sense, just a 3D printed frame to hold the electronics.

items.content_html:
My first exposure to the concept of this Mecanum omniwheel is during the VEX robotics competition back in JC, year 1 (2013, damn that's like 12 years ago). I honestly thought the seniors who bought the Mecanum wheels made the wrong purchase (still thought it's the wrong purchase, we definitely needed servos and stronger motors, not fancy omniwheels). We bombed the competition haha but in turn I got some experience sawing through the aluminum frames which so it was pretty fun all in all and playing with Mecanum wheeled robots.

Relatively simple on the electronics side, I originally considered using NRF24 for transmission but ended up deciding to try using purely WiFi, maybe also an excuse to force myself to make Android app for control.

[UPDATE] Made a quick Kotlin BLE Android App originally for the tank tread robot (here). The app is tested on the modular robot kit in a YT vid within the tank tread post. Unlike the tank tread robot which uses 2 seekbars for basic forward/reverse + turning, this mecanum robot will require full 2-axis joystick control for omnidirectional movement, so I will most likely just tack on a new mode to the app.

Straight forward circuit with ESP32, but needed 2 L298N modules since all wheels are independent, 1 L298N support 2 directions, I need independent 4 wheels. There are an onboard 2S LiPo battery (3.7V * 2 = 7.4V nominal, highest at 8.4V, lowest at 6V (not recommended to let it fall this low)) Also, I don't feel like designing a whole ass casing for the battery so I just gave it a platform, put 2 slots and cable tie the thing.

Basic movement for now, implemented using WiFi AP, I'm kind of curious how the direction fusion is implemented actually. The body is planned to be able to change shape (The right side move left, the left side move right, thus folding the body and the middle segment rises upwards), haven't got time to do it yet, but I provisioned a lot of modularity to do it on a later time when I am bored.

If I have a gripe with the wheels (cheap, ordered online), is that I would have liked it to have a hole on both sides, so that it is more stable, right now the weight of the middle segment bent the wheel a bit, it's like on a slight angle when its on the floor moving.

Also HTML based control interface is horrible, need to figure out how to use the BLE Android app with this one.

YT vid of the basic movement, this is done using the WiFi AP and legit only have the gamepad up-down-left-right buttons on an HTML page.

[Update] x-y controls and direction fusion using the basic 2 seekbar controls that I originally made for the tank tread robot

YT Vid here on Mecanum Omniwheel controls using the BLE Remote Controller App. I know I said above that I will tack on a new mode on top of the original tank controls / conventional controls, but I wanna do a quick experiment with the Mecanum direction fusion (x and y only, omega rotation control is omitted for this one) which worked wonderfully even if there's a small omega rotation drift which is expected cuz the build is pretty janky on the wheel side.

If you have never heard direction fusion prior to this, Mecanum omniwheels strongest feature is that the rotation of each wheel is able to determine sideways movement (x-axis) / forward backward (y-axis) and on the spot rotation (omega). items.content_html:
LEMME SHOW YOU WHAT THE ABYSS OF INSANITY LOOKS LIKE

Should I just buy a 2nd hand Squier or Ibanez or Pacifica to begin with? Yes.

Is making a whole guitar myself incredibly troublesome? Also Yes.

Why am I doing this? I dunno man, the guitar gods is telling me a modular guitar (as in swap out the pickups, not the neck, I am not that insane) sounded like a cool idea so here I am. I will definitely offend guitar traditionalists, man I was seen like a heretic when I said headless guitars make more sense in terms of the physics (and looked cooler) and now here I go making straight up modular guitars.

Man, I can't even play guitars...I can play piano and recorder a bit and even then it's half-assed at best.

I thought I can save a couple of hundred bucks on a guitar that I 3D-printed (cuz I'm a cheapo), it turned into a multi stage saga that spanned years (mostly due to procrastination, also cuz of an actual job) that goes into deadends a few times, where I went back to the drawing board to study actual mechanical principles, then consulting ChatGPT for hours on end trying to understand multiple configurations of 3D prints + carbon fiber tubes. Don't knock it till you try it, the suggestions it spewed is pretty solid and matches up with what I am already aware of.

I will also honestly say this is the toughest project I have done yet. Main reason being this is also the first time electronics took a backseat and mechanical principles is 80% of the work, as someone who is used to winging the mechanical design and casings without considering strength and flex of anything, this is very new but fascinating to me.

I damn nearly give up and about to just buy a damn neck, before I read up on how to "finish" the neck and holy shit it's still troublesome, just in a different way.

*sigh* Had to buy a PETG filament (ChatGPT suggested like Nylon and Carbon filaments too, which sounds expensive), and adjust the temperatures on Cura (PETG is 240/80, PLA is 192/60, ABS 230/100). First time using this filament, pretty cool, stronger than PLA and not as pain in the ass as ABS. ABS is supposedly the most "overpowered" but without a cover to maintain temperature, it's the most troublesome of the trio I mentioned above (also you won't believe the number of glue sticks I bought from Popular just to make sure the damn print won't wrap). The higher hotplate temperature occasionally also caused the microcontroller in the 3D printer to freeze and whoop-dee-doo there goes your progress.

V1. Failure of failures

This is the failed V1, supposed to be a foldable neck. Yes, I didn't read up on jack shit before starting V1, I know. Totally underestimated how much tension is being exerted on the whole neck, it detuned and bent on its own when I tried tuning for the 1st time ever. Horrible idea and blasted my self confidence back to the stone age :'^( Just joking, I had to put this aside for months as I moved house and joined a new job, then just getting distracted by 3-4 other projects and actual job.

Also, if you seen the image, you will notice that it is made to fold away from the string / fretboard side, the strings exerted so much tension it actually bent it in the opposite direction, into the fretboard direction.

V2. Overcompensation

I deadass fed this image to ChatGPT and try to get its opinion on the positioning of CF tubes

There's a truss rod (darker reddish orange thing between the 2 bright orange rods) on the upper 3/4 of the neck (Already, this deviates from the norm where the truss rod is firmly implanted the whole length of the neck, total of 4 CF tubes (2* OD10ID8 and 2* OD6ID4)

I split it into 4 parts for the neck: [BOTTOM] [MIDDLE] [TOP] [HEAD]

Printed BTM and MID at 80%, then TOP and HEAD at 90%. Changed the settings cuz I reckoned TOP and HEAD are thinner by design, has thinner CF tubes and the truss rod will not be epoxy'd will need the extra strength wherever it can get it. (Also TOP didn't take too long to print anyway)

V2 Body

Above is the body with the module inserted, I was going for a C-shaped body (still retain the right half of the telecaster shape, copied the measurements from another madman who made a 3D model LOL, I think he only wants to use it as a prop, not an actual guitar) and the module is inserted from the left. The module is going to contain the whole circuit, from the telecaster pickups, audio jack, the selector switch, and the 3 knobs for volume and tone.

Above is how it looks like with the module removed. You can see the guiding rail on the body now. There's 2 more CF tubes (OD6 ID4) reinforced prints behind the C shaped body to help resist the tension and toughen the whole print. This whole guitar will actually be on the thicker side with the back support.

Top X-ray view here, the long cylinder that extends into the body is the space for the CF tubes. I have split the whole body frame into TOP-MID-LOWRIGHT-LOWLEFT. TOP is connected to the neck, a CF tube will extend down through TOP-MID-LOWRIGHT.

The LOW (LOWRIGHT and LOWLEFT combined) part (rightmost in this rotated image) is initially way too huge for my liking and it will take forever to print, so I split them, but since the CF tube only went into LOWRIGHT, I have to connect LOWRIGHT and LOWLEFT in a sturdy way, thus 6 screws and nuts should do the job, I will also use epoxy + higher infill at the connection.

The Back support is shown here in this side view where it will act as an extra support frame for the C shape, the support connects TOP and LOWLEFT in this case. I was hoping that it will be a direct stiffening support to resist against tension when there is no module in place.

items.content_html:
From here on out, I will just refer to these arcade controllers as akecons (ã¢ã±ã³ã³, akekon) cuz typing the long name every time is really tedious. Why do I make this? Just nostalgia haha.

Main Module contains ESP32, this is also the "action buttons" side of the akecon. Connection and magnets is on the left side, shape is a bit weird cuz I am optimizing for space so that it's not as big as the typical akecons. Also I copied the measurements wholesale from a diagram I found on Google. There are lots of variants for the button arrangements, and I picked the one that looked the nicest and ergonomic.

The magnets is one of those door magnets you can get online. I used them during my research engineer stint at SIT and dayum they are strong. Action buttons are bought online too, they are pretty cheap.

Honestly, pretty straightforward in terms of circuitry, literally just solder the 8 action buttons to a PCB with ESP32. The ESP32 will just keep scanning for changes of state, yada yada. The main obstacle that actually got me to waste lots of time is the BT identifier thingie. The one that tells the PC what is it connected to? IIRC they are called something like "HID (Human Interface Device) Descriptor"

At first it was just some random numbers and it confused the PC, but after I mimicked the HID descriptor of my Logitech gamepad, it worked perfectly.

Changeable Module without ESP32, basically the "secondary" module, it is the "dumb" side and the connection is on the right, and I used the steel plates that comes with the door magnets I bought online.

The joystick part is also purchased online, and it's the ones used in commercial arcade machines. I honestly thought it's going to be analog like the PS2 joysticks, but it turns out to be digital, 4 contact switches for each direction. So I end up just treating the joystick side as if they are buttons too.

This is a variant of the Changeable module, this one uses 4 buttons and also a total of 5 pins on the connection to do the same thing as the joystick module. Yes, this is basically the "gamepad arrow buttons" on typical gaming controllers.

After I gave it more thought, I came to the realization that perhaps it would have been better to use 7-8 pins instead of 5 for the inter-module connection. 5 pins cuz GND + 4 directions (short sighted af, I know, I also want to whack the past me.)

If it got 8 pins, it means I can have total 7 pins on the left "dumb" module. Perhaps I2C (OLED screens and stuff) + analog stick is possible in that case.

YT vid here is showing connection test between akecon modules, action buttons and joystick test

Doing a quick gameplay on a lightweight game, the response time is decent, not some top tier wired gaming keyboard level thing, responsive enough that I can have a decent time in PVP.

Also if you are wondering why is there a USB wire when I clearly mentioned BT HID Descriptor? Just for 5V power from the USB. Back then I didn't put in too much thought on the battery side, just want a quick prototype and planned for a power module at the back of the main akecon module, but haven't got around to making one.

items.content_html:
Alright, big question, some agree with my views when I talk about it, some thought it's pretty "bruh". Partially a biography just in case my kids decided to ask me and I forgot details or something. Also a record about my dad and mum in case I forget anything.

Self-employment is the only way forward

Let's start from the beginning, my dad is a civil engineer manager working for a pulp and paper company, hardly got time for me back then when I was a kid but oh well such is life, he did his best. My mom is an admin, the head secretary for the regional branch in fact. From the way my parents talk about their time there, seems like it sucked balls, more for my dad, my mum is more neutral about it all.

They damn nearly sunk (financially) before my mum decided to do a hail mary and started a water filtering depot (Air minum ERSE at Perawang, you can look it up on Google Maps), good money, evergreen business actually. I have told Singaporeans about this before and they are honestly baffled at the idea and how it works, but in more ways than one, it is a genius idea:

  1. Everyone drinks water, and they LOVE water that is not dirty and don't taste like Chlorine (looking at you Newater)

  2. The first water depot store that passes the Government's health safety inspection (0 bribing, no sir.)

  3. My parents have connections into the factory in the town, and they are basically the sole supplier for years

My dad has another business running in parallel that started like a few years prior, it's a relatively small plantation for palm trees (Sawit in Indonesian). Also very good money, but it takes time to ramp up in production, around 4-5 years, basically a really long investment.

My dad's last biz as of this writing is swiftlet's nest, ççª. This one Singaporeans generally know, they are also really baffled when I am very flippant about my mum bringing those that are unsellable (flaky and thin usually) to SG and making soups of it for our own consumption. (They go like "Wah, aren't those really expensive!?") Well I mean the birds made the nests at the 4th floor of my parent's shophouse, why would it be expensive?

In essence, my dad semi-retired since the age of 40, he barely works just manage and keep things running, coming back and forth between SG and Indo once every 1-2 months for 10 days each time. Imagine having 100-120 days worth of annual leaves haha. My mum is a housewife since 2000, and while it is no less tougher than working, I would say it is a far more meaningful job (taking care and educating kids vs making money for some stranger).

I want that life for myself, and I want to have time for my kids in the future, the best path forward is to go this route as early as possible and making it work.

And if no girls want me sadge :'^( , I have 100 more hobbies I want to try out, being a wagie doesn't allow it. Thus, this is the way.

Also I will be brutally honest now, who in their right mind want to work until they are in their 60s then forced into retirement, what if you still have kids in uni? Are you okay with it? Ask yourself honestly and think for a bit, and no, don't start your reply with "Bo pian", that just drains your spite and motivation by half. You know the answer. Anyone knows the answer. How you respond is your own. I have Singaporean friends telling me it's impossible and it will be risking my career at a chance at this, but I will be damned if I don't at least try.

Hell fuck it, my career has been derailed since 2020, what do I have to lose?

Of course, I know some people who unironically thinks climbing the corporate ladder is the path to "adulting". You do you, I am simply saying the opinion of one who thinks otherwise. I say it sucks and they will never mention how you are never really in control, much less the fact that the "ladder" can be kicked out from under you

My basic assumption in life is self-employment trumps being employed by others, I guess, and this factors into a lot of my life's decisions.

Why learn so many skills? Why such a huge breadth from EE / ME / Material Science / IOT / Robotics / Biomed / Additive Manufacturing?

Independence in case I can't find a collaborator for a business. Worst case I will need to be a one-man-army for a while and I better be able to step up to that role.

My dad dabbled from civil engineering, built then designed the plumbing and electrical system of all 4 of his own shop houses, learnt how water filtration and cleansing works, learnt how to plant palm trees and grow them, learnt swiftlet's preferred habitat, how to attract them and the pacing on harvesting their nests.

My mom has background in aquaculture, climbed to head secretary in 5 years of working, side hustling the whole time, and the water depot was her idea, she is the one who first figured out who to hire to build the first iteration of the filtration system.

Compared to them, I looked like an over-specialized nerd haha. They basically did it all from nothing, no inheritance, no nothing other than their education. I have 10 times the resources and a higher education, what kind of massive loser will I be if I can't at least achieve the same level of success?

Also I have brought this up since the M.Sc. Mechanical Engineering posts.

It's "street cred" for a future business. Yes, I mean it 100%, now not even MBAs will question my credentials, isn't it?

Try to imagine if I am still B.Eng. trying to sell them an IoT product? Now I can shut them down by using the fact that I am the same level as them but Engineering.

I can do ME stuff long before this ME M.Sc. but now on paper, no one will question it.

Also I have been freelancing during the weekends this whole time (since at least 2023?) but that's beside the point, I would say it helped to boost confidence in me being able to create solutions and products that people want and willing to pay for.

I have been planning on self-employment before I even graduate B.Eng.

Zero-rent strategy

Now, SG rent is stupid expensive, I remember reading a headline in 2025 that a rental for a clinic is 52000 SGD per month. WTF. How are you supposed to make it back every month?

Indonesian pro-tip for biz: 0 rent + minimize expenditure = easy to make net profit. There are satay shops near my parent's house at Pekanbaru that has been open since the 1990s and there's barely anyone there, how is it still open? It's their own house LMAO, 0 rent thus they only care about making net profit, even if the revenue is only enough to make back the meat and ketupat (rice pack thingies), they don't care cuz the profit is just 0, not 0 minus rent.

Now taking note of the story above, Batam is now a no-brainer if my next step is self-employment, not continuing in SG. SG strat for biz is literally "go big or go bust", which sucks cuz even my parent's most profitable biz took a year to get going and 1 year of rent in SG is absolutely punishing.

Also another big reason is I have lots of stuff in SG haha, too many figures and plamos and since it's impossible for me to get BTO (need to rush to get a wife (3D human wife, not waifu) and I thought that's just a horrible idea) or condos (debt slavery for another 30 years) here, I chose the best option I have at the moment, easier to ship stuff to Batam than Pekanbaru. Thus, I sealed my path forward by buying a Batam home. A bit expensive relative to Batam's average houses but compared to SG, the bang for buck is so much better.

Minimize expenditure, extend runway, grow the biz, will be my main strategy

The Concept of a 'good deal'

I have people who told me that SG condo and BTO holds value better than Batam house. (Clowned on, even :^| )

Yea if I can buy em without sinking my whole life into a debt hole or derailing it with a rushed marriage, I would too.

They are not wrong, but I simply think my priority is different, that is all.

Short tangent time!

Option 1: Get a condo!

2-3 million SGD for basically what amounts to a chicken coop in the middle of the sky. By the gods do I hate shitty deals, hell I shit on Apple all the damn time for shitty deals. This is the shittest one of em all. If you want to flex, actually flex the whole way, get a landed property, now that's actually impressive, there's the huge upside too that you don't roll for nutjob neighbors above and below you.

IMO, people that advocates for condos typically just want the prestige of 5C and the idea you are no longer a normal "pleb" in an HDB. I don't really agree with it, especially when they start acting like they are better than everyone else.

Option 2: Get a BTO!

Need to rush a marriage = bad idea, I have seen people rushing to get married to do legal stuff and I swear 90% of them ends like shit. The guy loses half his fortune and the girl wasted their precious time. (Asian context, don't pull your whole western thing here, you know what I'm talking about, don't be slow.) I honestly just thought this is a horrible idea in every way possible.

Option 3: Resale HDB!

Ownership rules still the same BTO, need 2 PRs to own 1 and rushing marriage is my main gripe.

Also, here's a quick conspiracy theory :^) , SG feels like it's in a housing bubble, why else you think your gubmen keep importing new citizens? People want their HDB prices to keep rising, but citizens dun have kids, pop go down = demand for HDB go down. Demand goes down = Price goes down. People don't like price going down now, do they?

The main lever to keep price going up is by ensuring pop keeps going up. However, pop go up until when? Is SG not over-populated enough? What happens if people stop coming in or SG runs out of space?

Real estate investment in SG is good on the surface, but either it's the shittest deal on Earth or requires you to take insane risks as you rush for a BTO/HDB.

The spirit of being an engineer to me vs in SG

I have a small story to tell about my dad.

He used to be a civil engineer with hundreds of subordinates and construction workers under him to develop roads and bridges for the town of Perawang decades ago. As one can tell, their schedule can be irregular cuz their work is really affected by weather so they are also reliant on getting work done during OT hours. Then one day fuckin HR gave a decree that OT is suspended cuz some fuckwit up in corporate have been exploiting it, not thinking that such a heavy handed move will ripple down everywhere.

My dad responded by just asking his subordinates to work the office hours. Things goes to shit and half constructed roads lost their shapes within a week. He got called up to corporate to get berated maybe even demoted or fired.

This is where the twist comes in, in the meeting room he goes "OK now that you hauled me all the way here, may I know the fucking HR monkey who implemented that new brain-dead no OT rule?"

Yes, he intentionally got himself hauled to corporate just so he can go and berate the head of HR instead. He went all the way haha

Ohh no OT huh, you limp wristed HR lots think it's easy to work during thunderstorms in Perawang huh, how many lightning rods you installed over there for protection? That's right, Zero.

You fucks know how muddy it gets out there when it rains?

Why don't you get out of your comfy AC room and do the work for 1 week if you think it's so easy?

These construction workers is already barely making ends meet, hardly goes back to their family, and now they have to deal with moronic monkeys up here fucking every thing up like the monkeys you are.

After a long scolding sesh from this mere regional head of engineering to the HRs in front of the company owner and the C-Suites, somehow got the HR demoted instead.

To this day his former subordinates around Perawang and Pekanbaru still respects him and showed as such whenever they encounter one another.

A rare engineer win for once, I think even rarer in SG.

I think that also informed my worldview quite a bit

  1. Don't be a pussy, show up for your subordinates

  2. HR can be really stupid (and sometimes, they are pretending to be stupid so that they don't get sued *wink*), and they're definitely not your friend. We should not hesitate to fight back, but at the same time, fight back strategically. They're not omnipotent gods and even then, a god that bleed can also be killed. They are way more powerful than you, but so does a raid boss.

  3. Engineers are out here building real things, entire towns, cities even, have some damn pride in the craft.

I have seen my engineering managers in SG, be it in SME, Unis or Polys, groveling at HR, not complaining when they get voluntold to do stupid shit and scared of even getting into HR's field of view.

Here is an engineer, with decades worth of invaluable experience, groveling at what amounts to be the ultimate corporate lapdogs. There is just something deeply and profoundly, sad and pitiable about all this.

However in SG, you can't really escape HR, can you? As long as you are still someone's employee, you answer to HR, which is also another reason why I'm so hell-bent at self-employment.

If you are sick of corporate games and HR? Why not take the 3rd route? No one ever said you have to be in SG for the rest of your life, hell, to Singaporeans, the 3 months visa-free thing to lots of countries could become your main advantage, lots of countries want entrepreneurs and inventors. (You can be a respected asset with your own company in TW, JP, etc.) I don't think life is a zero-sum game, and I don't think one is a loser for not aspiring to the 5C. If SG corporates don't want to cherish or respect engineering, you are in great demand everywhere else.

I still want to be an engineer and build stuff, I just don't want to eat shit as someone's employee for the rest of my life.

Goddamn SG SMEs suck. Sometimes I want to give them the benefit of the doubt cuz my parents are indo SME owners and I plan to be one too, but my exp with SMEs in SG has been: "treated like disposable hot trash." Hard to sympathize when SME owners here whine that they are being crushed by MNCs.
